sub_topic: Probability of a certain outcome in a sports game
message_1: In a basketball game, a player has a 60% chance of making a free throw. If he takes 10 free throw shots, what is the probability that he will make exactly 7 shots?
message_2:
To solve this problem, we can use the binomial probability formula:

P(X = k) = C(n, k) * p^k * (1-p)^(n-k)

where:
- P(X = k) is the probability of making exactly k shots
- C(n, k) is the number of combinations of n items taken k at a time (also written as nCk or "n choose k")
- n is the total number of shots (in this case, 10)
- k is the number of successful shots (in this case, 7)
- p is the probability of making a shot (in this case, 0.6)
- (1-p) is the probability of missing a shot (in this case, 0.4)

First, we need to find C(10, 7), which is the number of ways to choose 7 successful shots out of 10:

C(10, 7) = 10! / (7! * (10-7)!)
C(10, 7) = 10! / (7! * 3!)
C(10, 7) = 3628800 / (5040 * 6)
C(10, 7) = 3628800 / 30240
C(10, 7) = 120

Now, we can plug these values into the binomial probability formula:

P(X = 7) = 120 * (0.6)^7 * (0.4)^3
P(X = 7) = 120 * 0.0279936 * 0.064
P(X = 7) â‰ˆ 0.2149908

So, the probability that the player will make exactly 7 shots out of 10 is approximately 21.5%.
